Award.AwardTitle: Trapped Rainbow on a Chip: Slowing Light Through Nanoplasmonics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to understand and develop novel graded-grating plasmonic nanostructures, capable of simultaneously slowing or stopping of light at multiple wavelengths, the so-called trapped "rainbow" effect. The approach exploits recent breakthroughs in simulation of metallic nanostructures, and introduces novel designs for this unique nanoplasmonic platform that will enable broadband trapping of light in photonic chips at arbitrary temperatures. Applications include optical buffers for ultra-high capacity optical communications.

Intellectual Merit

The vision of this research is to trap and release broadband light at telecom wavelengths through coupling to surface plasmon polariton (SPP) modes in novel graded-grating nanoplasmonic structures. Innovative design and fabrication schemes are advanced to overcome current fundamental performance limitations. Physical mechanisms and performance metrics are investigated by FDTD numerical simulation, including mechanisms for multi-wavelength trapping and release, light coupling enhancement, propagation loss, and pathways for increasing the photon lifetime of SPP modes. Selected experiments will be performed to validate simulations, fabricate nanoplasmonic test structures, and perform near-field imaging of the SPP modes. If successful, it would create a new paradigm for optical buffers in photonic integrated circuits.

Broader Impact

This research will provide exciting multidisciplinary educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students, directly impact Lehigh's photonics curriculum track, and promote K-12 outreach. The research promises fundamental breakthroughs in optical science, could have a transformative impact in the critical field of photonic integrated circuits. If successful it could open the door to commercial enterprises, and have a huge impact on high-capacity optical fiber communications by enabling long sought after optical buffers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In recent years, society has experienced an amazing growth in the data capacity of optical fiber networks, which continue to fuel our technological growth and support new ways of living and doing business. To meet this growing need, scientists have sought to drastically slow down the speed of light propagation, and to coherently stop, store, and release short optical pulses. This ability holds the key to the ultimate control of light and has profound implications for optical communications and quantum information processing. Most attempts to slow or trap light have relied on narrow resonances, which are not suitable for increasing the capacity of broadband optical information systems.

 

This project conceived and performed the first experiments that unambiguously demonstrated trapping of broadband light (i.e., rainbow trapping), using nanopatterned metal gratings to validate theoretical predictions for this exciting new class of nanoplasmonic structures. Highly focused beams of ions were used to mill a series of nanosized grooves into a thin sheet of silver. The resulting gratings were graded by slowly varying either the depth or period of the grooves across the grating. This technique, called Surface Dispersion Engineering, alters the optical properties of a metallic surface. Light was focused on the series of nano-grooves, and this graded plasmonic grating structure slowed or trapped each wavelength of light at different positions along the grating. The capture of individual colors of the visible spectrum at different groove depths (or periods) along the grating resulted in a trapped rainbow of light. This concept creates a new pathway for controlling and manipulating packets of individual photons in a laser beam over a very broad spectral range.

 

Employing the principles of surface dispersion engineering, a slowly graded chirped grating was designed for a silver film in the 400-700-nm wavelength region, and fabricated by focused ion beam milling. Preparation of the nanopatterned gratings required 'milling' a series of rectangular grooves in a 300-nm-thick silver sheet. The surface topology was accurately measured using highly sensitive atomic force microscopy. A nanoslit was then fabricated 13 microns from the left edge of the graded grating to couple free-space light incident from the bottom to surface plasmon modes on the top surface. These surface plasmon modes propagate along the graded grating until they reach a groove period (or depth) at which they are trapped.

 

In the experiments, the nanoslit was illuminated successively by white light and light emanating from the nanogrooves of the graded grating is observed from the top side by far-field optical microscopy. A colorful emission spanning the range from blue to red light is observed at different positions on the grating, demonstrating the rainbow trapping effect. Light of different wavelengths in the 400-700nm region is 'trapped' at different positions along the grating, consistent with the predictions of computer simulations.

 

Harnessing the power of light through the localization of light waves, i.e., by trapping them in nanoplasmonic metal films, represents a transformative, long sought achievement. This research creates the potential for unprecedented broadband trapping of light at the surface of metallic nanostructures, and advances the goal of coherent control and storage of light pulses on “photonic chips”. Realizing this goal could have an immense impact on applications such as high capacity optical fiber communications and quantum information processing. While earlier findings on this project were largely theoretical, later work reported the first unambiguous experimental demonstration of 'rainbow trapping' in plasmonic nanostructures at temperatures suited for practical applications.
